stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on Course 14, focusing on creating and programming a new 'paper spring' mechanic. He scrapped and began brainstorming a redesign for a snow biome area, had a creative breakthrough for a crayon-drawing mechanic, and discussed his broader philosophies on level design, difficulty, and community interaction.

development_findings.summary: A breakthrough moment occurred when Kaze, inspired by chat, decided the crayon item should be used to draw elements like bridges or reveal invisible platforms, evolving it from a simple key item into a core gameplay mechanic.
development_findings.quote: What if you use the crayon to draw something on the floor to make progress? Oh, now we are going somewhere.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is working on Course 14, which features a snow biome, Luigi's lost crayon, and a new 'paper spring' platforming object.

The physics for the new paper spring were iterated on, moving from a realistic but unpredictable 'jelly' behavior to a more 'fudged', player-friendly model that is predictable and controllable for platforming.
development_findings.quote: I don't like how the spring works. It's too jelly and it's too hard to make the jump.

development_findings.summary: Kaze experimented with applying texture filtering to game and HUD textures but ultimately rejected it, preferring the sharp, unfiltered pixelated aesthetic.
development_findings.quote: I think I prefer it like this over what I had before. ... Yeah, without filtering.

development_findings.summary: Kaze decided to completely scrap and redesign the 'Styrofoam mountains' area of Course 14 because he felt it was uncreative and visually unappealing.
development_findings.quote: I'm also thinking this whole section here that we had before with the Star of the Mountains looked like shit and I want to remake it.

development_findings.summary: Kaze confirmed that there will be no 100-coin stars in the game.
The level design intentionally supports and encourages players to find their own difficult, stylish, or sequence-breaking routes using advanced movement, without making them mandatory.
development_findings.quote: I could probably do like the first frame walking on the platform next to the star and then fly over to the other side... that's part of the fun I guess figuring out what works and what doesn't.

development_findings.summary: Kaze created a general-purpose function to handle sliding physics for objects like the crayon, aiming for more reusable and efficient code.

context_findings.summary: Kaze had a revelation inspired by Hazy Maze Cave that the best level design involves creating unexpected, seemingly random connections between elements to make the experience more memorable and unique.
context_findings.quote: I realized you kind of need to just do random shit. You kind of just need to be schizophrenic and make connections that don't actually exist in your levels to maximize on that concept.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes extreme difficulty is an accessibility barrier. He prefers creating games that are broadly playable but allow for optional, self-imposed challenges, citing Mario 64's movement as a core example of this principle.
context_findings.quote: Someone once told me that games being difficult is like an accessibility issue. And I can kind of see that. ...for me true difficulty means that it's actually like some people can't play your game.

context_findings.summary: Kaze defines freedom in game design as the player's ability to experiment with movement and actions without being punished, which he sees as a core strength of Mario 64.
context_findings.quote: Freedom is the ability to do things without a penalty basically.

context_findings.summary: Kaze displays a pragmatic view of legal risks from Nintendo, believing the company makes calculated business decisions rather than reacting emotionally to jokes or online taunts.
context_findings.quote: Nintendo is not one meathead that's like getting upset if you look at them the wrong way. They are a big company making calculated decisions. They're not going to make a decision based on just one stupid joke tweet.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's philosophy for changing core SM64 elements, like the HUD, is that any alteration must be a clear improvement on the original concept, not just an arbitrary change for the sake of being different.
context_findings.quote: When we make a change like that, we want it to be like the same thing, but improved.

context_findings.summary: The stream took place on Kaze's birthday, and his partner Zeina was present, having made him chocolate milk and bought a cake.

biobak.summary: Biobak was watching the stream and Kaze showed him the new crayon drawing mechanic to get his opinion.
Biobak participated in the stream chat, making jokes with Kaze.
biobak.quote: 90% of gamblers quit right before they win a bank. Don't forget.

zeina.summary: Zeina was present during the stream; Kaze mentioned she bought him a birthday cake and made him chocolate milk.
Kaze mentions a personal arrangement with Zeina regarding playing Ocarina of Time at Christmas, highlighting their personal dynamic.

key_stories.title: Fudging Physics for Fun
key_stories.summary: Kaze developed a new paper spring object, but its initial physics were too realistic and hard to control. He intentionally 'fudged' the physics, prioritizing predictable gameplay feel over pure realism, resulting in a much more enjoyable mechanic.
key_stories.challenge: The new paper spring mechanic felt too wobbly and unpredictable ('too jelly'), making platforming difficult and frustrating for the player.
key_stories.process: Kaze identified that the realistic physics were not fun. He adjusted code variables to increase the spring's stiffness and reduce its oscillation time after a jump. He tested it repeatedly, refining the feel until it was 'fudged' enough to be reliable for gameplay.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully implemented a predictable and controllable spring that still looked visually dynamic, making it a fun and reliable platforming mechanic rather than a frustrating one.
key_stories.key_quote: This is less realistic. But it should work. Just be more predictable for the player. ... That does feel very predictable now.

key_stories.title: The Crayon's New Purpose
key_stories.summary: Kaze was struggling to make a crayon-retrieval mission interesting. A viewer suggestion sparked a creative breakthrough, transforming the crayon from a passive key item into an active tool used to draw platforms and bridges, solving the design problem.
key_stories.challenge: A key mission in Course 14, retrieving Luigi's lost crayon, was shaping up to be a boring fetch quest with no engaging gameplay.
key_stories.process: Kaze was unhappy with the simple 'walk there and back' design. He brainstormed ideas like breakable walls and buttons. A breakthrough came from a viewer suggestion, which led him to the idea of using the crayon to draw solutions directly into the level.
key_stories.outcome: The crayon was reconceptualized as an active tool. The new plan is for players to use it to draw things onto the world, like bridges or revealing hidden platforms, to solve puzzles and progress, making the mission an engaging journey.
key_stories.key_quote: What if you use the crayon to draw something on the floor to make progress? Oh, now we are going somewhere.

key_stories.title: The Hazy Maze Cave Revelation
key_stories.summary: Feeling his level design was becoming stale, Kaze re-examined Hazy Maze Cave and had a revelation. He decided its strength was its 'randomness' and embraced a new design philosophy: create more surprising experiences by making unexpected, schizophrenic connections between level elements.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze felt his level design for Course 14 was uninspired and was particularly dissatisfied with the 'Styrofoam mountains' area.
key_stories.process: While discussing Mario 64 levels, Kaze had a sudden re-appreciation for Hazy Maze Cave. He analyzed its strength as coming from its 'random' elements, like finding a sea monster in a toxic cavern, and decided to apply this 'schizophrenic' design principle to his own work moving forward.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze adopted a new guiding philosophy for level design, aiming to create more memorable and surprising levels by juxtaposing seemingly unrelated ideas, much like he perceived Hazy Maze Cave did.
key_stories.key_quote: I realized you kind of need to just do random shit. You kind of just need to be schizophrenic and make connections that don't actually exist in your levels to maximize on that concept.
